properties.project_description: The project includes construction on St. Helens Avenue, from 6th Avenue to Division Avenue, including the intersection of 6th Avenue. Improvements will consist of an asphalt grind and overlay from curb face to curb face along with bulbouts at the intersections and installation of active transportation features (bike facilities and crosswalks). South 2nd Street, from Tacoma Avenue to Court C is also being repaved, and a new sidewalk installed on the south side of South 2nd Street, from Tacoma Avenue to St. Helens Avenue.
properties.project_rationale: Roadway is in very poor condition and pedestrian facilities are below typical standards. PW Board Loan funds available.
properties.phase_notes: Construction has been completed.

properties.projname: East Lincoln Ave Bridge Seismic Rehabilitation
properties.project_description: The East Lincoln Bridge Project will enhance the seismic resilience of the existing bridge by replacing its current bearings, which are vulnerable to seismic events.
properties.phase_notes: Working towards 30% design.

properties.project_description: Crews will grind out sections of pavement to make minor repairs and prepare the surface for the placement of a 2-inch layer of asphalt over the existing street surface. ADA curb ramp upgrades will also be made at this time if applicable.
properties.location_description: S 12th from S Cedar to S Sprague
properties.phase_notes: The project is currently in design phase.

properties.project_description: This project will rehabilitate the roadway and add curb and gutter, sidewalks on the east side and a shared use path on the west side of Sheridan Ave. from S 72nd St to S 64th St. Utility improvements include Power pole relocation, Stormwater, Sanitary Sewer and Water improvements that will occur prior to the start of roadway construction. Other amenities include landscaping, trees and retaining walls.
properties.location_description: Sheridan Avenue from S 72nd Street to S 64th Street
properties.project_rationale: Sheridan Avenue is a north-south, two-lane arterial in the heart of South Tacoma, providing critical access to businesses, parks, emergency services, and residential neighborhoods. It also serves as a key connector to major east-west arterials, including South 56th, South 64th, and South 72nd Streets. Currently, the roadway has significant alligator cracking in the wheel paths and along the shoulder edges. The existing sidewalks are substandard, noncontiguous, and non-compliant with ADA standards. Additionally, bicycle access is undefined and unsafe due to the deteriorating road surface.
properties.phase_notes: Project has been awarded for construction. Future phases to complete the improvements to S 56th St. are yet to be funded and are in the planning stages.

properties.projname: Baker Middle School Safe Routes to School
properties.project_description: This project will improve safety and walkability by adding sidewalk with curb and gutter, ADA compliant curb ramps, bulb-outs, marked crosswalks with advanced stop bars, a rectangular rapid flashing beacon, and a hybrid beacon. Speed bumps will be added to lower vehicular speed, further improving safety for all non-motorized users. Bicycle safety will be improved using green pavement bicycle crossing markings and providing a protected bicycle boulevard conversion with wayfinding signs and markings. In addition to corridor improvements, walk/bike school events, encouragement activities, and safety education classes will be provided at the end of construction. This project was prioritized based on safety, equity, and connectivity metrics.
properties.location_description: Baker Middle School, J and 84th to Yakima and 80th
properties.project_rationale: This project will address community requests for Safer Routes to Schools and supports Transportation Master Plan policy 2.6 Safer Routes to Schools.
properties.phase_notes: Working towards 90%

properties.project_description: This project will upgrade the seismically vulnerable columns along the South 48th Street Bridge. The columns upgraded will be the two columns centered between the northbound and southbound I-5 lanes.
properties.location_description: South 48th St Bridge (between Tacoma Mall Blvd and S Alaska St)
properties.project_rationale: Inspection reports done justify the need for column jacketing
properties.phase_notes: Construction is estimated to begin Winter 2025.

properties.projname: McKinley Ave ITS and Signal Coordination
properties.project_description:
This project will provide traffic signal communications and traffic signal coordination on McKinley Avenue between E 38th Street and E 64th Street. This includes upgrading traffic signal detection, replacing signal cabinets and controllers, installing Accessible Pedestrian Signals, and installing fiber optic communications at networking equipment. It also includes the full reconstruction of the McKinley Avenue at E 56th Street traffic signal which includes curb ramps and sidewalk connections. The following intersections are included:
  • 38th and McKinley
  • 40th and McKinley
  • 48th and McKinley
  • 56th and McKinley
  • 64th and McKinley
properties.location_description: McKinley Ave and E 38th St/ E 40th St/ E 48th St/ E 56th St/ E 64th St
properties.phase_notes: Obligated March of 2025

properties.project_description: This project will construct a two-mile bicycle boulevard on J Street from North 3rd Street to South 27th Street, along with improved east/west bicycle connections via 6th Avenue, South 11th Street, Earnest S Brazill Street, South 17th Street, and South 18th Street. The five east/west connections, ranging from one to three blocks in length, will provide access to Link Light Rail stops and key neighborhood destinations including the Hilltop Business District and People’s Community Center.
properties.location_description: J Street - from N 3rd Street to South 27th Street Intersection
properties.project_rationale: This project reflects community desires to decrease speeding, improve safety, increase bicycle connectivity through Hilltop, and will fill a critical gap in Tacoma’s bike network.
properties.phase_notes: Project is in construction.

properties.projname: Pedestrian Mobility & Safety Improvements at South 56th St and Pacific Ave
properties.project_description: This project will address the pedestrian safety concerns at the South 56th Street and Pacific Avenue intersection. There are currently numerous non-ADA compliant features, including the existing curb ramps, pedestrian pushbutton locations, and planters blocking the pedestrian path. As part of this project, all four corners of the intersections will be reconstructed to provide two ADA-compliant ramps per corner. New pedestrian push buttons will be installed at accessible distances from curb ramps. Bulb-outs will be implemented to reduce pedestrian crossing distances, improve pedestrian visibility, reduce speeding, and better align the intersection. Sidewalk improvements to provide accessible sidewalk access to nearby transit stops will be included as-needed. The roadway pavement will be improved through a grind and overlay and minor stormwater improvements and channelization will be included.
properties.location_description: S 56th St and Pacific Ave Intersection
properties.project_rationale: Politically charged project with an accident having occurred at the intersection
properties.phase_notes: Working towards 90%

properties.project_description: This project will improve safety on Portland Avenue from East 27th to East 56th Street by slowing speeds and improving connectivity for people walking, rolling, and bicycling. Tacoma’s Vision Zero Action Plan (www.cityoftacoma.org/visionzero) uses a data-driven approach to set Tacoma’s path towards eliminating crashes that cause serious injuries or deaths by 2035. In addition to actions to improve safety citywide, the Plan identifies roadways that are the highest risk for serious injury & fatal collisions. Portland Ave is one of these high-risk corridors. When completed, this work will compliment planned light rail and transit improvements and the planned regional Tacoma to Puyallup trail. This project directly connects to the Pipeline Trail and significant community destinations. The City of Tacoma will be working closely with the Puyallup Tribe of Indians, as well as community and transit partners to improve safety and multimodal access along one of Tacoma’s highest crash corridors.
properties.project_rationale: This project improves safety and provides safe bicycle and pedestrian access.
properties.phase_notes: Currently in Design.

properties.projname: Puyallup Avenue Corridor Improvements with Pedestrian Access to Fife
properties.project_description:
Reconstruction of a roadway with complete street elements including sidewalks/curb ramps, bulbouts, crosswalks, signals, lighting, landscaping, bus stops, upgraded utilities, and a shared HOV/transit lane, as well as minor improvements to side streets to reorient/increase functionality of parking spaces, and other street amenities. The pavement design for driving lanes
will meet heavy haul standards.
 
Bike lanes/active transportation facilities will also be added, with additional State funds, to provide Fife to Tacoma pedestrian access, adjust the ramp at the Portland/Puyallup intersection, and connect this project’s amenities to WSDOT’s regional bike lane improvements along SR 167.
properties.location_description: Portland Ave to 450 feet east of Eels Street/20th Street East intersection
properties.project_rationale: Encourages neighborhood revitalization, supports transportation, including non-motorized needs.
properties.phase_notes: The project is currently in the design phase. A start date for construction has not yet been set, as full project costs and funding are not yet known. Construction is anticipated to occur at some point between 2027-2031.

properties.projname: South 11th St and Ernest S Brazill Protected Bike Lane Couplet
properties.project_description: Fill a critical missing link in Tacoma's bikeway network along S 11th St and Earnest S Brazill. The construction of planned bicycle facilities would require narrowing vehicle lanes along South 11th Street and Earnest S Brazill.  This project also includes intersection upgrades with improvements including bicycle detection, accessible pedestrian signals, and accessible curb ramps.
properties.project_rationale: This project improves safety and completes a gap in planned bike lanes
properties.phase_notes: Currently in design.

properties.projname: S Cedar St Active Transportation Improvements
properties.project_description: This project improves walking & biking by constructing crosswalk improvements, buffered bike lanes, ADA improvements, sidewalk, channelization, bike detection, signal improvements, and engineering evaluation.
properties.location_description: S Cedar St from S 15th to Center St
properties.project_rationale: This project will provide safe bike and pedestrian access from S 15th to the Scott Pierson Trail. It will improve ADA accessibility, pedestrian access, and wayfinding signage.
properties.phase_notes: This project is in ROW phase.

properties.projname: S Orchard Street/Lakewood Drive (S 56th Street to S 74th Street)
properties.project_description: This project will complete street design in partnership with Lakewood and University Place. Having a design will make the project more competitive for grant opportunities to fund construction.
properties.location_description: S Orchard Street/Lakewood Drive (S 56th Street to S 74th Street)
properties.project_rationale: Planned partnership with University Place and Lakewood to improve/replace roadway, pedestrian facilities, and crossings along the corridor. Potential for joint grant application.
properties.phase_notes: No funds available for additional design and construction.

properties.project_description:
Project to Construct a multiuse path along the Schuster Parkway linking downtown Tacoma/Thea Foss Waterway at S. 4th Street with the Old Town District
at N. 30th.
properties.location_description: Schuster Parkway, S. 4th to Ruston Way
properties.project_rationale: Active transportation is a fundamental aspect of a sustainable transportation system. This project is included in the multi modal priorities of the Transportation Master Plan and will help complete the Dome to Defiance regional non-motorized system.
properties.phase_notes: A design consultant team, KPG Psomas, was awarded the project design contract at the February 4th 2025 council meeting. The contract was executed shortly after award and the project design has commenced starting with topographic survey.

properties.project_description: This project will replace the remaining Fishing Wars Memorial Bridge spans (Phase 2) over the Puyallup River and eastward towards Fife.  Work will relocate power lines  located just north of the bridge and possibly include work on the Milwaukee - Puyallup Avenue intersection.  Sewer lines and other telecoms on the bridge will be affected.
properties.project_rationale: The Fishing Wars Memorial Bridge replacement project addresses critical infrastructure needs supporting economic activity and user benefits for the Port of Tacoma, the Puyallup Tribe, the surrounding industrial area, and the Cities of Fife and Tacoma.  The bridge is currently closed pending cleaning and inspection and is in need of replacement.
properties.phase_notes: Project will enter design phase in 2024.

properties.projname: Historic Water Ditch Trail- Phase III & IV
properties.project_description: Phase IV is complete.  Phase III will complete 1.1 miles of shared use trail between Pine and M Street on the north side of South Tacoma Way and a sidewalk between Pine and Sprague on the south side of South Tacoma Way.
properties.project_rationale:
Funding Availability/ Opportunities, Other Funding Opportunities
City Council and South Tacoma Neighborhood Council priority project
properties.phase_notes: Phase IV is complete.  Phase 3 will be built in two stages.  Phase 3A 'M' Street to Sprague is under construction and will wrap up in 2025. Phase 3B Sprague to Pine Street will begin construction summer 2025.

properties.project_description:
This project will make improvements to or construct over 130 new ADA-compliant curb ramps, impacting 21 total intersections, that have been requested by people with disabilities and where there are identified barriers. This will improve access to between streets and sidewalks for people with mobility issues. This project will create an accessible, walkable, and equitable community within District 10.

The following intersections are included with this project:
•	S 46th St & S J St
•	S 52nd St & S I St 
•	S 54th St & S J St 
•	S 54th St & S K St
•	S 54th St & S I St
•	S 59th St & S I St
•	S 62nd St & S Bell St
•	S 64th St & S L St
•	S 68th St & S I St 
•	S 68th St & S J St
•	S 68th St & S K St
•	S 68th St & S L St
•	S 68th St & Thompson 
•	S 70th St & S J St
•	S 70th St & S I St
•	S 70th St & S K St
•	S 70th St & S Thompson Ave 
•	S 78th St & S Fawcett Ave
•	E 43rd St & E McKinley Ave
•	E McDacer & E Tanglewood Ave 
•	E 35th St  & E L St
properties.project_rationale: Complaints have been voiced regarding the safety of existing non-compliant ramps and community members have been tracking the progress of this project
properties.phase_notes: Construction

properties.project_description: This project will improve the overlook area along East 32nd Street and provide a useable, public greenspace for the community. Included in this project are planted landscape areas with a sidewalk pathway, interpretive signing, viewfinders, garbage cans, seating, lights, and defined parking spaces. This space will make use of the viewpoint and promote active transportation, improve safety and limit vehicular speeding, reduce littering, and build a cohesive sense of community. Future placemaking and arts will be incorporated throughout the project after construction is complete.
properties.location_description: E 32nd St from  E E St to E F St
properties.project_rationale: This is a high priority, community-driven project for CM Ushka
properties.phase_notes: Construction done end of March 2025

properties.project_description: Extension of an eight-inch wastewater main within North 48th Street from Lexington Street east 150 feet, thence south in Lexington Street, approximately 680 feet.  Lexington Street and North 48th Street will be paved with 2-inches of asphalt over 4-inches of crushed surfacing top course to an approximate width of 28 feet on Lexington Street and an approximate width of 20 feet on North 48th Street funded by Street Initiative No. 24.
properties.project_rationale: A majority of property owners abutting the street have signed an advisory petition.  Formation hearing on December 14, 2020.  Hearing Examiner recommended formation.  Formed by Council,  ordinance 28743,  3/16/2021.
properties.phase_notes: Project anticipates construction to occur in 2024-2025.

properties.project_description:
This project will complete road repairs and reconstruction from East 38th Street to East Sherman Street, including pedestrian bulb-outs, accessible ramps, and construction of sidewalks where current gaps exist. 

The project's arterial improvements will occur at the same time as improvements to side streets associated with the Streets Initiative #27 package.
properties.project_rationale: The pavement on E Roosevelt is currently deteriorated, with a failed subgrade for the majority of the project area. E Roosevelt Ave is a significant arterial that connects Eastside community members, including residents of the Salishan Tacoma Public Housing Authority development and Puyallup Tribal Housing Authority properties, to community amenities including the Roosevelt Elementary School, Eastside Family Resource Center (WIC Center), NAMI Pierce County (mental health resource center), Roosevelt Park and Swan Creek Park, and Puyallup Tribal early childhood center. E Roosevelt Ave is also the core transit route for Pierce Transit route 41 connecting residents to Downtown Tacoma and the Tacoma Mall area, Tacoma's largest economic and educational opportunity areas. E Roosevelt Ave is currently missing sidewalks and ADA ramps on both sides of the street along long stretches of the corridor and lacks safe and accessible access to the school, resource center, parks, and transit stops. Adoption of revised zoning regulations, which include upzoning this area to Urban Residential 2, will more than double allowed density by reducing required lot size standards and allowing for additional housing types (such as multi-family housing up to 6-plexes). The areas anticipated increase in density is expected to amplify the existing community needs for enhancements to this corridor.

properties.project_description: Grind and overlay with curb ramp/signal improvements and associated utility upgrades.
properties.location_description: Yakima Avenue from Earnest S Brazill Street to I Street Transition near S 7th Street
properties.project_rationale: The pavement in the project area has deteriorated to the point where it is in need of an asphalt overlay to preserve the pavement’s service life.

properties.project_description: This project will grind & overlay 6th Avenue from the intersection at S Yakima Ave to the intersection at St Helens Ave, and a portion of Tacoma Ave S from approximately S 5th St to S 7th St. Channelization may extend beyond these points. Pedestrian accessibility will be improved at pedestrian crossings within the scope of the project to meet ADA compliance and existing bikeways will be refreshed/revised. Bike lane revisions can be made within existing ROW and no acquisition is required.
properties.location_description: 6th Avenue from the intersection at S Yakima Ave to the intersection at St Helens Ave, and a portion of Tacoma Ave S from approximately S 5th St to S 7th St
properties.project_rationale: The pavement in the project area has deteriorated to the point where it is in need of an asphalt overlay to preserve the pavement’s service life.
properties.phase_notes: Planning stage completed, preparing for design phase.

properties.projname: S 11th Street and S Sprague Avenue Signalized Intersection Improvements
properties.project_description: The project aims to install ADA-accessible curb ramps, accessible pedestrian signals (APS), leading pedestrian intervals (LPI), high-visibility crosswalk markings, 12-inch signal heads with retroreflective backing, programmable signal heads (northbound and southbound), and video detection.
properties.location_description: S 11th St and S Sprague Ave
properties.project_rationale: The existing loops are failing, which creates the signal to need to be operated in a fixed time environment.  A fixed time signal is not as efficient, which can create additional pollution to the environment. The video detection system provides the ability to optimize traffic flow safely and efficiently.  The ability to detect bicycles for the proposed protected bicycle facility on S 11th St, will help activate the signal system for bicycle users, when vehicles are not present.  To communicate back to the office, which saves time and money versus going to the intersection in the field to verify operation.  The communication between the intersections will be enhanced so that the signals work in coordination with each other.
properties.phase_notes: Currently in the Planning Phase.

properties.projname: S 56th St & A St Crossing Improvements
properties.project_description: At the intersection of A St and S 56th St, the project will construct high visibility crosswalks, a pedestrian hybrid beacon (PHB) signal system, a traffic diverter median, and curb ramps.
properties.project_rationale: A St is designated as a future bicycle boulevard in Tacoma's Transportation Master Plan and runs parallel to Pacific Avenue (SR-7), providing an alternative route for active transportation modes. Pacific Avenue is a high-volume state highway with no bike facilities. S 56th St is another high-volume (10,000 ADT est. 2015) principal arterial that acts as a barrier to people walking and biking in the neighborhood on A St. The City of Tacoma's Vision Zero safety plan identifies both arterials as part of the city's High-Risk Network, which are streets with a concentration of severe crashes, indicating a need for safety improvements. The project is in a neighborhood that rates low on the City of Tacoma's equity index with 39% persons of color, 13% disabled, 12% poverty rate, and significant environmental health concerns from air pollution and heavy traffic. A safer, signalized crossing of S 56th St is essential to improving active transportation access to schools, parks, and transit stops.
properties.phase_notes: Currently in Planning Phase

properties.project_description: Engineering, procurement, installation, commissioning and startup of a third compressor to the existing Solid Waste Management's CNG Fueling Station to provide for increased fueling capability and reliability for this critical asset.

properties.projname: SW 2025 CIPP Rehab in Various Areas
properties.project_description: This project consists of 4,234 LF of trenchless rehabilitation of 15-inch through 24-inch diameter stormwater mains in various locations. The underground stormwater mains in these various locations are reaching the end of their design life and are at risk of failure.

This project will rehabilitate the roadway and add curb and gutter, sidewalks on the east side and a shared use path on the west side of Sheridan Ave. from S 64th St to S 56th St. Utility improvements include Power pole relocation, Stormwater, Sanitary Sewer and Water improvements that will occur prior to the start of roadway construction. Other amenities include landscaping, trees and retaining walls.
properties.location_description: Sheridan Avenue from S 64th St to S 56th St
properties.project_rationale: Council requested project to complete missing sidewalks, improve traffic safety and enhance the active transportation connections.
properties.phase_notes: Project is currently in design awaiting grant application for construction funding.

properties.projname: WW Sewer Repl - War Memorial Park, 624 N Meyers St
properties.project_description: This project consists of the removal and replacement of existing 902 LF of 10-inch diameter wastewater mains in War Memorial Park with additional miscellaneous abandonment of existing wastewater mains in various areas. This project also consists of removal and replacement of wastewater mains in E. K. St. and adjacent to 1112 Puyallup Ave.

properties.projname: Pacific Avenue Vision Zero Improvements (Schuster Parkway - City Limits)
properties.project_description: This project would enhance safety for all roadway users and increase pedestrian accessibility and safe crossing opportunities. This project will also enhance bicycle connectivity to transit and destinations along Pacific Ave from parallel neighborhood greenways and east-west bike routes. This project is likely to be phased.
properties.location_description: Pacific Avenue (Schuster Parkway - southern City Limits)
properties.project_rationale: Pacific Avenue is one of Tacoma's highest risk Vision Zero corridors. This project meets multiple strategic goals and priorities including place-making, catalyzing development, and providing active transportation options.
properties.phase_notes: Community engagement underway as part of Picture Pac Ave project and Tacoma-Pierce County Health Department Health Impact Assessment.

properties.project_description: This project consists of replacing the pavement, adding bike lanes, replacing sidewalks and curb ramps to meet ADA standards, upgrading the stormwater system, upgrading the illumination system, and adding LED lighting between McKinley and Portland.
properties.project_rationale: Roadway is in very poor condition and grant opportunities are available. This project will create a complete street.
properties.phase_notes: This project will begin road construction July 2024. The base lift of pavement is in along with the majority of the sidewalk on the western half of the project.   Beginning in 2025 work is now focusing primarily on the eastern half of the project.

properties.project_description: The City was awarded a Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) grant to construct needed safety improvements at selected intersections along the 6th Avenue corridor between Jackson Avenue and Grant Avenue.
properties.project_rationale: Project will increase pedestrian crossing safety at 19 intersections along 6th Avenue from Jackson Avenue to Grant Ave.
properties.phase_notes: Project bids have been received and are being evaluated.

properties.project_description: The project will enhance the corridor along Sound Transit’s Hilltop Tacoma LINK extension route to increase accessibility and safety for residents and businesses. The scope of the improvements includes varying sidewalk color and designs, pedestrian lighting, street furniture, wayfinding signage, bicycle facilities, local art, granite inscriptions and poetry, street trees, and landscaping. The project serves one of Tacoma’s oldest historically Black neighborhoods and business districts, and the design was informed by nearly two years of grassroots outreach to the Hilltop community. Downtown: On the Go!, Hilltop Action Coalition, and Tacoma Housing Authority all assisted in the outreach effort. The final design is informed and defined by the community that it will serve and will honor the history of the corridor.
properties.project_rationale: Project will incorporate concept of "Complete Streets" within Upper Tacoma mixed use zoning district increasing utility capacity, creating Urban Villages and providing for build out of adjacent parcels.
properties.phase_notes: Bid Package 3 is nearly complete, Bid Package 5 started construction Sept. 2024, Bid Package 1 bid opening April 22, 2025.

properties.projname: S 21st St & C St Signal Project
properties.project_description: This project will replace traffic signals and update pedestrian infrastructure. New signal assets will include signal poles, push buttons, circuitry, and conduit. Curb ramps will be updated as needed for ADA compliance.
properties.project_rationale: Improve pedestrian access between UWT and Tacoma's Brewery District, improve vehicular access to SR 509/705, reduce crashes and serious fatalities.
properties.phase_notes: Construction is under suspension for coordination with the Prairie Line Trail Project.

properties.projname: WW CTP Thermophilic Digester Tower A Restoration and Improvements
properties.project_description: Rehabilitate and coat the existing concrete surfaces at the A Quad Towers at the CTP Thermophilic Digesters to repair and prevent erosion.  Also install access hatches at ground level for maintenance access.

properties.projname: SW - Sewer Replacement Various Areas - N I ST, S 50th, S 15th, S 42nd
properties.project_description: Replace aging utilities and upsize stormwater sewer pipes at various locations to prevent overflow. This project will also include required street restoration improvements.

properties.projname: WW E Division and E F Street Sanitary Sewer Replacement
properties.project_description: Replacement of Approx. 1004 LF of 8 in. Sanitary Sewer Pipe

properties.projname: Point Defiance Regional Treatment Maintenance Project
properties.project_description: This project will repair all concrete that has cracked and spalled at the Point Defiance Regional Treatment Facility
This project will replace deteriorated wastewater sewer mains in the Wapato area.

properties.projname: 6th Ave & S 19th St Railroad Crossing Improvements
properties.project_description: Pedestrian rail crossing improvements are planned at both the 6th Avenue and S. 19th Street rail crossings. Select improvements include upgraded railroad signals, relocated vehicle railroad gates, the installation of new pedestrian railroad gates, sidewalks, curb ramps, pavement replacement, pavement markings/crosswalks, landscaping, signage and fencing.
properties.location_description: 6th Avenue and S. 19th Street rail-road crossings
properties.phase_notes: Project is currently in the Ad/Award phase. Request for Bids to be released in May 2025.

properties.project_description: The City of Tacoma will work with a consultant to develop an ADA Transition Plan and Self-Evaluation that meets all state and federal requirements. The Self-Evaluation component of the ADA Transition Plan will be a comprehensive assessment of all facets of accessibility in Tacoma’s public right-of-way. It will include measurements of accessibility criteria for sidewalks, curb ramps, traffic signals, bus stops, and driveway curb cuts in the public right-of-way, as well as an assessment of existing policies and procedures. The Self-Evaluation phase will also include a significant public outreach and involvement effort to assist the City in identifying issues and prioritizing projects. Other components of the ADA Transition Plan will identify all barriers to accessibility in the public right-of-way, describe methods that will be used to achieve accessibility, create a prioritized schedule to remove barriers, and identify the person responsible for the implementation of the plan. The plan will incorporate City of Tacoma actions and policies outlined in the Vision Zero Plan, Transportation Master Plan, and Comprehensive Plan.
properties.project_rationale: The plan will incorporate City of Tacoma actions and policies outlined in the Vision Zero Plan, Transportation Master Plan, and Comprehensive Plan.
properties.phase_notes: The grant was awarded January 2024. No grant match funds have been secured. The City is working on a Request for Proposals to seek for qualified companies to provide consulting services to develop an ADA Self-Evaluation and Transition Plan for the City.

properties.project_description: The project will provide an enhanced driving surface on the Northbound and Southbound ramps to/from Interstate 705 and the Tacoma downtown area. This project will install a new cement concrete overlay on the ramp decks, new bridge deck expansion joints, and safety upgrades including a new crash attenuator at the beginning of the Northbound ramp.
properties.location_description: The project is located on the I-705 on/off ramps connecting to South Stadium Way/Commerce Street.
properties.project_rationale: The existing ramp/bridge decks made of reinforced concrete is currently delaminating in several areas. Current side barrier height along the ramps/bridges does not comply with safety standards. Lastly the crash attenuator where the northbound ramp to Stadium Way begins has previously been hit in a vehicular accident and needs replacement. This project will provide a new concrete overlay of the ramp/bridge decks, new side barrier railings to comply with current height requirements/safety standards, and a new crash attenuator replacement.
properties.phase_notes: Contract Awarded to Combined Construction Inc. Anticipated start of construction is May/June 2025. Schedule details are being determined and will be provided once available.

properties.project_description: The project extends along the Portland Avenue corridor from the north leg of Lincoln Ave to the north leg of E. 27th Street, and east along Lincoln Avenue approximately 200 linear feet to the Lincoln Avenue bridge deck. The project includes the replacement of asphalt pavement with concrete, roadway re-channelization as needed, bicycle facilities as needed, addition of a new traffic signal at the SR-509 off ramp, upgrades to three (3) existing signals to add interconnects at all four traffic signals, installation of ITS Fiber Optic, replacement of unsafe/unfit sidewalks and addition of missing link sidewalks, installation of ADA curb ramp improvements and a new mid-block pedestrian crossing with push button activation, and bridge deck repairs/resurfacing including expansion joint repair as conditions warrant. Construction schedule is unconfirmed as funding is not yet secured.
properties.location_description: Portland Avenue between Lincoln Avenue and East 27th Street
properties.project_rationale: Portland Avenue serves as a major access route for freight traffic between the Port/Industrial area and Interstate-5.  Preserving access is key to the economic vitality of the south sound. Portland Avenue is also an auto priority corridor in the City's Transportation Master Plan.
properties.phase_notes: Design is near 100% complete. Environmental Documentation is currently incomplete and will be followed by necessary ROW phase tasks.

properties.project_description: This project is approximately 1.3 miles in length and is located on S. 25th Street between the Scott Pierson Trail and Prairie Line Trail. The project includes installing bicycle facilities such as bike lanes, shared lane markings, parking protected bike lanes, bicycle wayfinding signage, green bike lane pavement markings, bike box, bike detection, and a shared use path. So as to maintain the existing road width, parking on the north side of S. 25th Street approximately between S. State Street and S. "J" Street will be converted to bike facility space (see figures below with conceptual bike facility striping/channelization).  The project also includes installing marked crosswalks and curb ramps, and implementing leading pedestrian intervals as needed at locations along S. 25th Street approximately between the Scott Pierson Trail and Hood Street. Project includes associated ADA and utility work as needed.
properties.location_description: Along South 25th Street approximately from Scott Pierson Trail to Hood Street
properties.project_rationale: This project provides a much needed connection between the Scott Pierson Trail and downtown Tacoma.
properties.phase_notes: Project is working towards completing 90% design, and starting Right of Way (ROW) tasks once ROW funding is authorized.

properties.project_description: This planning study will assess 14 existing I-5 bridges/undercrossings in support of federal "Reconnecting Communities Pilot Program." This project supports WSDOT's I-5 Systems Partnership to reduce barriers that I-5 creates in the community.
properties.project_rationale: This project will identify improvements necessary to address barriers to active transportation within the community surrounding Interstate 5.
properties.phase_notes: This project is in the planning phase with the expectation that a consultant will be secured Spring/Summer 2025 to complete the study by the end of 2026.

properties.project_description: Streets Initiative Package 18 project includes the construction of new roadway sections, asphalt grind and overlay, new catch basins, storm sewer infrastructure upgrades, curb ramp improvements, sidewalk repair where feasible, and curb/gutter repair as needed.      The project also includes roadway drainage/storm water improvements near the Crystal Springs Creek crossing. The roadway prism crossing Crystal Springs Creek will also be reconstructed.
properties.phase_notes: Design is near 90% completion. Environmental design and permitting is forefront of design being unable to be completed.

properties.project_description: ***Construction Update: Project construction is complete as of 4/2025.*** Project Description: The project will improve the roadway and utility infrastructure by rehabilitating driving surfaces for vehicles and bicycles, installing bike lanes and other bike facilities to encourage active transportation options, replacing curb ramps to meet ADA standards, replacing/upgrading existing storm sewer utility lines, installing new storm sewer utility lines where necessary, and installing runoff water treatment to improve water quality for new pollution generating hard surfaces within the project. Planting of trees, artistic elements in the form of concrete stamps, and historical sidewalk stamp preservation is also a part of the project where feasible. Construction began on July 15, 2024 and is anticipated to continue through Winter and spring 2024/2025 (weather dependent). Bike facilities installed in the project include traffic diverters at the intersection of East 34th Street and East "I" Street. An informational letter regarding the traffic diverters installed at East 34th Street and East "I" Street was mailed to the neighborhood in June of 2022 and can be viewed by clicking the following link. E 34th and I Diverter Notice
properties.phase_notes: Construction is complete as of 4/2025.

properties.project_description: This project would restripe the City roadways, bicycle facilities, crosswalks, other lane markings, and reflectors.
properties.project_rationale: This project has Transportation Master Plan Policy Support through 2.3 Improve Safety. This project will address community requests for striping maintenance and other striping to assist with traffic calming and crash reduction.
properties.phase_notes: Project is currently in process of awarding the contract after bid submittals in response to the project advertisement were opened on May 13, 2025.

properties.project_description:
New channelization and asphalt repair. The high volume of traffic, along with the heavy loaded tractor trailers, has deteriorated the asphalt roads beyond repair and has reduced the visibility of the channelization striping in 
several key areas. In addition, the existing gate controls cannot be upgraded and require replacement to allow for remote operation should the need arise during an emergency.

This project will remove the existing 1.5" grout layer on the bottom of the Central Treatment Plant secondary treatment tank and Epoxy inject and repair any cracks/spalls that have developed in the concrete.

properties.projname: WW - AN3105 Picks Cove Pump Station Rehab
properties.project_description: This project will focus on the rehabilitation of various structural, mechanical and electrical components at the Pick's Cove pump station.

properties.projname: WW CTP BSST Transfer Pump Replacement Project
properties.project_description: This project will remove and demo the existing BSST transfer pumps and replace them with new pumps, valves, and controls. These improvements will extend the serviceable life of the facility.

properties.projname: WW 2025 CIPP Rehab in Various Areas
properties.project_description: This project consists of rehabilitating 6,562 linear feet of 15-inch diameter wastewater mains in various Tacoma locations. The underground wastewater pipes in these various locations are reaching the end of their design life and are at risk of failure.
Replacement of air release valves (ARV), along CTP outfall to Commencement Bay, which are at the end of their useful life.

properties.projname: WW Side Sewer Improvements - McKinley Rd
properties.project_description: This project consists of installing new side sewers along McKinley Rd in order to transfer services to the wastewater main in the road. The existing main is at the end of its service life and located on private property, preventing routine maintenance and replacement of the pipe. Once the side sewers have been rerouted, the existing main will be abandoned.

properties.projname: Leach Creek Stormwater Holding Basin Modifications
properties.project_description: The purpose of this project is to improve operational efficacy of the Leach Creek Regional Stormwater Holding Basin.  The work consists of excavating a channel through the holding basin between the pump station forebay to the outlet structure. This work will allow us to increase the pump station run times during peak storm events improving the management of stormwater into and out of the Leach Creek Regional Stormwater Holding Basin.

This project will replace approximately 5,850 linear feet of 8-inch diameter public sewer main in the vicinity of S. 74th & Warner. The mains within this project are nearly 70 years old and are beyond their design life.  Project includes partnership with Water and Public Works.

properties.projname: WW, SW, & SWM Replace Various Areas - Landfill-Tac Ave - N 2nd St
properties.project_description:
This project will replace deteriorating wastewater and stormwater sewers at various areas in Tacoma to ensure service is maintained and reduce need for future emergency repairs.

Sites at: N Tacoma Ave between N 1st and N 2nd St and several locations at the Tacoma Landfill.

properties.projname: Streets Initiative Package 38 - Slurry Seal Project 2024
properties.project_description:
This maintenance project includes the application of slurry seal to various streets to preserve and prolong the integrity of existing roadways. Slurry seal is a combination of emulsified asphalt and aggregate that are mixed and placed over the existing asphalt surface. This product is designed to protect and preserve the existing asphalt surface and prolong its integrity.

To allow crews full access of the street "No Parking" signs will be posted in the neighborhood 72 hours before work starting onsite. Vehicles that remain within the area of "No Parking" areas will be towed at the owner's expense. If this happens you may contact the Tacoma Police Department at 253-798-4721 and Bills Towing at 253-272-9393. Your cooperation in removing your car will help crews complete the work in a timely manner.
properties.location_description: This maintenance project is generally located in Tacoma's West End and North End neighborhoods and will take place on various streets within the neighborhhods
properties.project_rationale: This maintenance project will proactively preserve and prolong the integrity of existing roadways by applying a slurry seal to the existing asphalt pavement.
properties.phase_notes: The slurry seal asphalt surface treatment work is suspended. Estimated start is mid to late June 2025 (Weather Dependent). "No Parking" signs will be placed along streets scheduled for application of slurry seal at least 72 hours before work begins.

properties.projname: Puyallup Ave Sewer Utility Replacement Project
properties.project_description: This project will replace, reroute and rehabilitate wastewater and stormwater trunk mains ranging in size of 42-in to 72-in.  Due to the location and size of the trunk systems, removal of the bridge at Puyallup Ave and B St may be necessary.
properties.location_description: A St from S 25th to Puyallup Ave & Puyallup Ave from A St to E C St, South Tacoma Way and S C St
properties.project_rationale: This project is to eliminate the stormwater flooding at S 26th and Pacific and replace trunks that are past their useful life and are located under a building.
properties.phase_notes: The City has completed the 2-step procurement process and has selected IMCO/Carollo as the Design-Build team.  Notice to Proceed (NTP) was issued for April 1, 2025.
